name: Start (readme)
info:
# Setting up your battery strategy flow

## Setup
Name the Link In in this start group exactly after the option configured in your
select_input.house_battery_strategy

found in the file:
input_select_house_battery_control.yaml

### example
`house_battery_strategy:
  name: House Battery Strategy
  options:
    - AcmE example`

Will point to the flow containing a Link In node
called 'AcmE example' (case sensitive).

name: Home Battery Strategy
info:
The `Home Battery Start` flow will call this strategy flow
by matching the strategy name with the Link In name.

Configure the Link In node in the Start group.

Don't modify other parts of the Start and End groups.
They handle the calling and returning for you.

name: return
End (readme)
info:
Should return a solution_array of battery objects

## battery object format
`{{id: string|number, mode: string, power: number}} battery solution`
- id is an arbitrary battery ID
- mode is "stop", "charge", "discharge" for Marstek
- power in Watts

### example array
return this type of solution_array
` 
let solution_array = [];
solution_array.push({id:"M1", mode: "charge", power: 100}); // per battery
return {payload: solution_array};
`

name: Advanced settings
Set: Error signal
Bumpless target grid consumption
info:
The error value is used by default to calculate the derivative.
When the target grid consumption (tgc) is changed, the system is takes the derivative of the process variable instead.
This prevents irratic behavior during sudden changes of the error or setpoint value.

e.g. you change the setpoint from 0 to 100W 
The error would make an instantanious jump and cause a huge derivative-term.
The pv stays continous and fluent.

After 1 control tick the derivative is taken from error again.
Until the `tgc` is changed again.
